US/Portugal culture: fast food
The US has exported its fast food culture all over the world, but much of Portugal is still immune. While the big malls have Burger King, McDonald’s, KFC and Pizza Hut in their food courts, you won’t find them elsewhere except in the larger cities.
What you’ll find instead are the churrasqueiras, or grills. These are locally owned businesses, usually staffed by the owners and their families. Some have seating, though it’s often rather superfluous since the vast majority of their customers order takeaway. They offer several types of grilled meat, including pork ribs, but by far their biggest seller is chicken.
Using grill racks similar to but larger than those used for sardines, the cooks flatten a whole chicken butterfly-style into the rack and set it over the grill. This is the healthiest fast-food chicken I’ve ever seen. Cooked over a real fire and basted in a sauce of olive oil and spices, it’s low-fat and absolutely delicious. Not to mention incredibly cheap—we can feed our family of three for ten euros.
The not-so-healthy part of the meal is the fried potatoes, or what I knew as French fries. Note: nobody over here, and by“here”I mean Europe, calls them French fries. The French didn’t invent them, nor are they known for making particularly good ones. Actually some of the best fried potatoes I’ve had were in Belgium (which claims their invention), but the Portuguese version is very close. What makes them so good is the same thing that makes them so unhealthy—they’re double-fried. The first dip into the oil is just to give them the idea. Then they’re set aside until a customer places an order, at which point they’re dunked again. The result is piping hot fries with a perfect combination of hardened exterior and soft, fluffy interior.
I am utterly addicted to these fries. Since I have a 9-year-old stepson, we are occasionally obliged to visit the Burger King in the mall (because it’s exotic!), and those fries are garbage. I can’t believe I used to think they were good.
Some churrasqueiras sell their fries by the serving, others by weight. Where they’re sold by weight, the staff display a rapid routine in which they whip a piece of paper onto the scale, dump a scoop of fries onto it, toss salt over the top and then twist the paper into a cone, all in about six seconds. Fries at a churrasqueira are easy, cheap, delicious and entirely too tempting.
The chicken is also served in a rapid-fire manner. The cook forks it off the grill and onto a tray, then grabs it with a pair of tongs and uses scissors to cut it up. Next he plucks a paintbrush from the sauce bowl and bastes the pieces. By default, the“normal”sauce is used, but if you request piri-piri, you get the spicy stuff. (Piri piri is a hot red pepper, ubiquitous in Portuguese cooking.)
A paper lid is placed on top and the foil edges of the container are pressed down, resulting in a heat-retaining, recyclable takeaway container. The whole process takes maybe 20 seconds. Watching these folks at work during the dinner rush hour is something to see, and will completely blow one’s image of the laid-back Portuguese.
Other than the churrasqueiras and the pizza joints, there really isn’t a fast food culture here. Then again almost every restaurant offers takeaway, so maybe there is a fast-food culture, just not American style. Food is one of the things that is still inexpensive in Portugal, and it’s often cheaper for us to order takeaway than to make a meal at home. Not only that, but the takeaway can be quite healthy, because it’s produced by locally-owned restaurants—meaning not much is preprocessed—and the main source of fat is olive oil.
I don’t miss American fast food. What I do miss, however, are taco stands—which aren’t really American at all, but a perfect combination of Mexican tradition and US business style. At the moment I would kill for a good spicy pork soft taco with lime juice and salsa.
Oh, well. The grilled chicken leftovers in the fridge will do for now.

Speaking of suckling Pigs have you ever visited the Bairrada Region between Porto and Aveiro?
